nodes.title: Telepresence Manifesto (2018 redux)
nodes.description:
today in critical theory, we read and discussed a few ‚Äúmanifestos for the internet age‚Äù. i‚Äôve got a cold so i called in; when the class broke out to create their own manifestos, i decided to write a ‚Äútelepresence manifesto‚Äù from my sniffly blanket fort.

turns out marvin minsky beat me to it. for context: minsky, who said ‚Äúi don‚Äôt think there is any such thing‚Äù regarding human consciousness, co-founded MIT‚Äôs AI laboratory. MIT has a long history of military research; in recent years, its public focus has shifted to military robots, drones, and battle suits.

his manifesto creeps me out. i changed ‚Äúhands‚Äù to ‚Äúdrones‚Äù to emphasize why. Edits left as strikethroughs; emphasis my own.

Marvin Minsky’s Telepresence Manifesto (1980) (2018 redux)

You don a comfortable jacket lined with sensors and musclelike motors. Each motion of your arm, hand, and fingers is reproduced at another place by mobile, mechanical droneshands. Light, dexterous, and strong, these droneshands have their own sensors through which you see and feel what is happening. Using this instrument, you can “work” in another room, in another city, in another country, or on another planet. Your remote presence possesses the strength of a giant or the delicacy of a surgeon. Heat or pain is translated into informative but tolerable sensation. Your dangerous job becomes safe and pleasant.

‚Ä¶

Telepresence is not science fiction. We could have a remote controlled economy by the twenty first century if we start planning right now. The technical scope of such a project would be no greater than that of designing a new military aircraft.

A genuine telepresence system requires new ways to sense the various motions of a person‚Äôs hands. This means new motors, sensors, and lightweight actuators. Prototypes will be complex, but as designs mature, much of that complexity will move from hardware to easily copied computer software. The first ten years of telepresence research will see the development of basic instruments: geometry, mechanics, sensors, effectors, and control theory and its human interface. During the second decade we will work to make the instruments rugged, reliable, and natural.

i hate reading this. he‚Äôs so excited about it. engineers need to think harder about what they propose. and ‚Äúgreat engineers‚Äù rarely deserve the title.

nodes.title: unhitching
nodes.description:
The possibility, vital for life, of unhitching, which consists‚Ä¶ in grasping, during the brief intervals in which our species can bring itself to interrupt its hive-like activity, the essence of what it was and continues to be, below the threshold of thought and over and above society: in the contemplation of a mineral more beautiful than all our creations; in the scent that can be smelt at the heart of a lily and is more imbued with learning than all our books; or in the brief glance, heavy with patience, serenity and mutual forgiveness, that, through some involuntary understanding, one can sometimes exchange with a cat.

nodes.title: making nothing
nodes.description:
here‚Äôs a post that i wrote during my second week here. now that the showcase is coming up, i need to start making a thing. guess i‚Äôd better put this up before that starts :)

one of my major goals during this program is to not make things.

* silence. the sfpc showcase curators back away slowly to discuss what a mistake they‚Äôve made. *

it‚Äôs okay, i‚Äôll do the assignments and make a showcase project and all that. i‚Äôm still going to make things. it‚Äôs hard not to; i‚Äôve already made a lot of Things since arriving, more than i‚Äôm comfortable with. but i‚Äôm celebrating all the things i think of that i don‚Äôt make.

during the binary numbers assignment, i came up with an idea to:

  • map binary digits (bits) to piano keys
  • find binary numbers that resolve to nice chords
  • create a simple matching app that prompts players with a decimal number and celebrates when the correct chord is played

i have a midi keyboard here, and i‚Äôve written a few programs already that interface with it. throwing this sketch together would have been easy. tbh it would have been an easy way to show off in class too. but just by thinking it through, i‚Äôd already gotten as much out of it as i was ever going to. building it would have come from a compulsion, not from any actual question or need. and it would have taken time, and space. for what?

there‚Äôs a passage in Madness, Rack, and Honey that i love:

if you have any idea for a poem, an exact grid of intent, you are on the wrong path, a dead-end alley, at the top of a cliff you haven‚Äôt even climbed.

moving to new york ‚Äì even from a big city like toronto ‚Äì i‚Äôm struck by the overabundance of stuff here. stuff to buy. stuff to eat. stuff to stuff your apartment with. it‚Äôs a good reminder that less can be more.

nodes.title: border crossing
nodes.description:
headed back to canada for the weekend to see the AGO‚Äôs yayoi kusama exhibit (RAD!) and attend a funky dance (RAD!). i‚Äôm back at the airport now and made it through (phewf). explaining this school at customs is always complicated, and i‚Äôve been pulled into secondary each time.

with this week‚Äôs readings on ‚Äúsecurity‚Äù + surveillance for our crit theory course (‚Äúthe radical outside‚Äù) fresh on my mind, the customs experience was heightened. last time reached an ABSURD level of invasiveness with questions about my family. this time was just lots of silence as i pondered what the neural nets were cooking up.

lil thought: upon saying i quit my job just over a month ago, the agent said ‚Äúoh - that‚Äôs a really long time‚Äù. Work is a weed we‚Äôre feeding üå± neoliberal capitalism, ‚Äúwe eat for you‚Äù, soapbox, etc.

anyway, glad i‚Äôm leaving all these keywords on a subdomain of my personal site for some cruel robot to scrape! typing from my phone so bye!
